title: Adventures in Accessibility
overviewtldr:
TL;DR

An ongoing personal project to solidify my web accessibility knowledge by building core UI components that fulfil accessibility standards. I build these first in HTML & ES6, then again in React.

Results:

  • Accessible Accordion
  • Accessible, Custom-styled Radio Buttons
  • Accessible, Custom-styled File Upload
overview:
Working in web development, I am continually struck by how much of the web is built on a handful of key components.

Beneath every beautiful designed site or application lies the building blocks of the web - file inputs, radio buttons, checkboxes, accordions, and more.

I wanted to take a step back and ensure I really understood the accessibility implications of these unsung heroes.

This project is my opportunity to solidify best accessibility practice, as I build a collection of components - first in HTML & Vanilla JS, then again in React.
ux:
The components were developed in isolation, without a specific user-group in mind. The objective was to create a solid, accessible baseline from which the components could be adapted and evolved as required.

Consequently, the colours adopted were either related to other personal projects, or arbitrarily chosen. The colour combinations selected all meet the WCAG Level AAA contrast ratio.
a11y:
I created a list of requirements the components needed to meet (and that I had the resources to test). This list was adapted from the published advice of accessibility experts and standards groups.

I do not pretend to have met all user cases, and the initial testing was conducted by myself, using built-in Android and Mac accessibility tooling.

This is not, and is not intended to act as, a replacement for diverse user testing.
result:
Each component is hosted on CodeSandBox, and has been written up individually as a series of blog posts. Please click the component that interests you from the list below:

  • Accessible Accordion
  • Accessible, Custom-styled Radio Buttons
  • Accessible, Custom-styled File Upload

title: Nihongo Scotland
tags: React, Styled Components, SCSS, Gatsby, Prismic
overviewtldr:
TL;DR

A ongoing side-project for a Japanese language study-group in Edinburgh. Built with Prismic, Gatsby, React, and Styled Components.

Results:

  • WIP site
overview:
Nihongo Scotland is a Japanese language club in Edinburgh, Scotland. The club offers Japanese students the opportunity to practice their conversation skills, in-person, with native speakers.

The primary offering, 'Friday Night Study Club', is a casual, drop-in, donation-based session. The club also offers paid 'bootcamps' - intensive weekend courses, providing complete Japanese-language immersion.

The goal of this project was a holistic overhaul their online presence, beginning with branding, content strategy, and the Nihongo Scotland website.
ux:
Process:

  • Brand Workshop
  • User Interviews
  • Remote User Testing

User Interview Results:

Semi-structured Interviews with existing club members informed the design as below:

  • Copy must be kept to a reading grade suitable for non-native English speakers
  • The website will be a brochure site, providing club time, location, and information. There is no current need to provide an online equivalent of the offline experience.
  • Bootcamp content is important - a large number of members found the page via their interest in / attendance at the Bootcamps


User Testing Results

Remote mobile testing was conducted via TryMyUI.com. 5 users who had an interest in, or some experience of, learning Japanese, performed initial impression testing, and worked through a handful of tasks.

Testing revealed:

  • Large logo on mobile prevents immediate comprehension of site services
  • Not immediately clear where the classes are held
  • Confusion around top-left 'home' button
  • Need for images
  • Need for testimonials on homepage

Wireframe refined after 1st round of user testing:
a11y:
I created a list of requirements that I wanted the components to meet, and that I had the resources to test. This list was adapted from the published advice of accessibility experts and standards groups.

Initial testing was conducted by myself, using built-in Android and Mac accessibility tooling

This is not, and is not intended to act as, a replacement for diverse user testing.
result:
The basic layout was created with an emphasis on reusable, decoupled components. Margins were managed through an isolated spacing component to further enhance the reusability of each component.

User testing will continue at regular intervals as the design, layout, and content are continually refined.

Performance requires further optimisation.

Images and reviews will be added when available.

title: Vue vs React Comparison
tags: React, Redux, Vue, Vuex, SQL, PHP
overviewtldr:
TL;DR

An MSc dissertation project from August 2019, comparing React & Vue performance in the context of modifiability and adaptability

Results:

  • React project GitHub
  • Vue project GitHub
overview:
A comparative evaluation of the maintainability, extendability and scalability of React.js and Vue.js.

Requirements change, and as such code change, is inevitable. The aim of this project is to critically evaluate React.js and Vue.js for their extendability, maintainability, and scalability, by first implementing a Minimum Viable Product (MVP) using each framework, and subsequently introducing change requests.

The MVP for both applications will be developed to an identical design and requirements specification, to ensure a fair baseline for the subsequent evaluation. A full set of metrics will be run on the respective MVPs to serve as a baseline for the comparison. The metrics will then be rerun once both applications have been extended.

The application built was intended for use as a Project Management (PM) tool for a web development agency, who do not feel their use cases are met by existing PM tools.
ux:
Process:

  • Competitor audit
  • User Interviews
  • Contextual Inquiry
  • Personas
  • Customer Journeys
  • Paper Prototypes
  • User Testing

Initial Research Results:

Interviews and contextual inquiry uncovered that the project management problem the company was facing was not really a tooling problem. The problem lay more in workplace culture, process, client education, and transparency around resource allocation.

Stakeholder Needs:


Ideation

A solution was scoped that included:

  • Structured ticket creation interface for clients, written to a non-technical reading grade.
    This is intended to improve the issue documenting process and ensure that all information is provided without an extensive back-and-forth.
  • Calendar View to display tasks per resource
    This is intended to improve transparency for management, and for team members to create a more connected culture
  • Reusable ticket types for tasks with common checklists
    This is intended to nurture process and support the continuous flow of contract workers

title: London on a ShoeString
overviewtldr:
TL;DR

A mobile-first responsive web application built using VueJS and TypeScript, pulling data from the Living Social public API and including 2 random generation functions.

Results:

  • London on a ShoeString Site
  • London on a ShoeString GitHub
overview:
Living in a new city is an enriching experience, but a limited budget can put limitations on how much you can explore.

When I did my Japanese translation fellowship with the United Nations in Geneva, I was so terrified of how much anything cost that I ended up barely seeing or experiencing anything.

The idea for this applications is to pull coupons and deals for London, to show how someone on a limited budget might still be able to make the most of everything the city has to offer.

Think Groupon, but simplified - the top 10 best deals for that day, and a random deal selector for when even browsing 10 options feels like too much cognitive load. No more choice paralysis. 'London on a ShoeString'.
ux:
Time-constraints meant that a lean UX approach was undertaken. The problem the site was intended to solve is the cognitive overload and dark UX patterns (playing on scarcity to invoke urgency in the user) observed on current deal sites.

The solution was a stripped-down, fun, bold, and simple to comprehend list of the top ten current deals.

The proto-persona was envisioned as someone young, not wishing to scroll through endless options, but just be presented quickly with top options for the days and weeks ahead.
